articles.headline: Russia Tried to Isolate Itself, but Financial Ties Called Its Bluff
articles.snippet: Even countries with limited trade relationships are intertwined in capital markets in today’s world. Could the Russia sanctions change that?
articles.abstract: Even countries with limited trade relationships are intertwined in capital markets in today’s world. Could the Russia sanctions change that?
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States, Europe and their allies are not launching missiles or sending troops to push back against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, so they have weaponized the most powerful nonmilitary tool they have available: the global financial system.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: On the Exodus West, Ukrainians Flee Hardship for an Uncertain Future
articles.snippet: Many thousands of Ukrainians, fearful of the war, are leaving their homes on a slow journey west, enduring difficulties but also buoyed by the generosity of their countrymen.
articles.abstract: Many thousands of Ukrainians, fearful of the war, are leaving their homes on a slow journey west, enduring difficulties but also buoyed by the generosity of their countrymen.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIITIVTSI, Ukraine — The families staggered in, bleary-eyed, to a two-room kindergarten around 1 a.m., exhausted after a long journey from their home in Cherkasy, about 300 miles away. Fearful of the threat from the Russian invasion, they had decided it was time to leave, and make their way along with tens of thousands of others to the safer regions of western Ukraine.

articles.headline: Last Vestiges of Russia’s Free Press Fall Under Kremlin Pressure
articles.snippet: “Everything that’s not propaganda is being eliminated,” a Nobel Prize winning editor said as Russian authorities moved to control the narrative in the Ukraine war.
articles.abstract: “Everything that’s not propaganda is being eliminated,” a Nobel Prize winning editor said as Russian authorities moved to control the narrative in the Ukraine war.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Vladimir V. Putin wages war against Ukraine, he is fighting a parallel battle on the home front, dismantling the last vestiges of a Russian free press.

articles.headline: Kremlin Vows Victory in Ukraine as Refugees Swell to One Million
articles.snippet: Defiant Ukrainians slowed the invasion, but Russian forces gained ground in the south, and the Kremlin insisted the week-old campaign was “going according to plan.”
articles.abstract: Defiant Ukrainians slowed the invasion, but Russian forces gained ground in the south, and the Kremlin insisted the week-old campaign was “going according to plan.”
articles.lead_paragraph: ODESSA, Ukraine — Russian forces advanced deeper into southern Ukraine on Thursday, appearing intent on seizing the country’s entire Black Sea coast, as the number of people fleeing Ukraine reached one million just a week into Russia’s invasion and bombardment of cities and towns.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: How Ukraine’s Military Has Resisted Russia So Far
articles.snippet: Ukrainian troops have mounted a stiffer-than-expected opposition to a superior force in the early days of the war. But U.S. officials say it may not last.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian troops have mounted a stiffer-than-expected opposition to a superior force in the early days of the war. But U.S. officials say it may not last.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ukraine’s soldiers have blown up bridges to halt advancing Russian ground troops. Its pilots and air defenses have prevented Russian fighter jets from conquering the skies. And a band of savvy Ukrainian cyberwarriors are so far beating Moscow in an information war, inspiring support at home and abroad.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Panel Suggests Trump Knew He Lost the Election, Eyeing Criminal Case
articles.snippet: At the core of the theory of a possible criminal case against former President Donald J. Trump is the argument that he knew he had lost the election and sought to overturn it anyway.
articles.abstract: At the core of the theory of a possible criminal case against former President Donald J. Trump is the argument that he knew he had lost the election and sought to overturn it anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after the 2020 election, as ballots were still being counted, the top data expert in President Donald J. Trump’s re-election campaign told him bluntly that he was going to lose.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Female Entrepreneurs Who Confront a Particular Kind of Troll
articles.snippet: Food companies founded by Asian American women find social media engagement with customers helps their growth, but they also face racist and sexist comments.
articles.abstract: Food companies founded by Asian American women find social media engagement with customers helps their growth, but they also face racist and sexist comments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fly By Jing, an artisanal food business in Los Angeles, is known for its Sichuan chili crisp and good-humored online presence.

articles.headline: Economic Ties Among Nations Spur Peace. Or Do They?
articles.snippet: The Russian invasion of Ukraine strains the long-held idea that shared interests around business and commerce can deflect military conflict.
articles.abstract: The Russian invasion of Ukraine strains the long-held idea that shared interests around business and commerce can deflect military conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russia’s war in Ukraine is not only reshaping the strategic and political order in Europe, it is also upending long-held assumptions about the intricate connections that are a signature of the global economy.

articles.headline: Strong Job Growth Continues as Latest Covid Wave Eases
articles.snippet: The U.S. economy added 678,000 jobs in February and unemployment fell to 3.8 percent, the lowest level since the pandemic took hold.
articles.abstract: The U.S. economy added 678,000 jobs in February and unemployment fell to 3.8 percent, the lowest level since the pandemic took hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: Falling coronavirus caseloads brought a flood of new jobs and new workers last month, signs that the pandemic’s vise grip on the economy may be loosening.

articles.headline: How China Embraces Russian Propaganda and Its Version of the War
articles.snippet: In much of the world, Russia is losing the information war over Ukraine. In China, though, it’s winning big.
articles.abstract: In much of the world, Russia is losing the information war over Ukraine. In China, though, it’s winning big.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hours after Russia invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, the Chinese Communist Party tabloid, Global Times, posted a video saying that a large number of Ukrainian soldiers had laid down their arms. Its source: the Russian state-controlled television network, RT.

articles.headline: In These Women’s Hands, Dating Is Truly the Stuff of Horror
articles.snippet: The filmmakers behind “Fresh” worked to avoid being exploitative as they injected comedy into their commentary on the exploitation of women.
articles.abstract: The filmmakers behind “Fresh” worked to avoid being exploitative as they injected comedy into their commentary on the exploitation of women.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the comedy screenwriter Lauryn Kahn first tried her hand at horror, a friend told her to write about the thing that scared her the most. She chose dating. After all, what’s more terrifying than relying on blind faith and a few Google searches to determine whether a complete stranger is a dud, a narcissist or, worse, a charming sociopath?

articles.headline: Decades of Neglect Leave I.R.S. in Tax Season ‘Chaos’
articles.snippet: A shortage of staff and equipment has stalled America’s fiscal machinery.
articles.abstract: A shortage of staff and equipment has stalled America’s fiscal machinery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the Internal Revenue Service’s sprawling Kansas City, Mo., processing center, teams of clerks earning $15 per hour work through the night, trying to help the agency clear a backlog of more than 20 million tax returns that are a year overdue.
